issues.description: The UML in the problem statement names Ride's second attribute shortCode (char), while the solution defines the corresponding attribute and getter using the name 'abbreviation' (char) and getAbbreviation(). This name mismatch between the UML/specification and the solution (and the empty template) can confuse students about the exact attribute/getter name they should implement (e.g., getShortCode() vs. getAbbreviation()).
issues.suggested_fix: Make the attribute name consistent across artifacts. Either (A) update the UML/problem statement to use 'abbreviation' (char) and document the getter name getAbbreviation(), or (B) rename the field and getter in the solution/template to shortCode (char) with getShortCode(). Ensuring consistent attribute names avoids student confusion about the expected getter name.

issues.description: The UML/problem statement names the Ride attribute as 'shortCode: char' (and thus students will expect a corresponding getter like getShortCode()), but the solution implementation uses the field name 'abbreviation' with getter getAbbreviation(). This is a naming mismatch for the same conceptual attribute (a short identifier for a Ride) and will confuse students who map the UML description to the code (and may also cause tests that expect the UML name to fail).
issues.suggested_fix: Rename the Ride field and its accessor in the implementation to match the UML name. For example, change the field 'abbreviation' to 'shortCode', update the constructor parameter accordingly, and provide a getter getShortCode(). Also update all subclasses and usages (constructors in LaunchedDropdownTower, LaunchedRollerCoaster, etc.) to use 'shortCode' so names are consistent with the problem statement UML.
